newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: NSW moves to isolate effect of fire blight.
newsitem.headline: NSW moves to isolate effect of fire blight.

text.p: Movement of apples, pears and nursery stock from the Australian state of Victoria into the state of New South Wales (NSW) had been banned following reports of fire blight in Melbourne's Royal Botanic Gardens, NSW Agriculture Minister Richard Amery said in a statement.
The bacterial disease represented a major threat to fruit industries throughout NSW, he said.
The banning lessened the risk of spread of the disease, which was not present in NSW, he said.
Victorian authorities were surveying the state to determine areas free from fire blight, he said. The NSW government had begun an extensive survey of orchards and nurseries in its state.
The Australian apple and pear industry has an estimated gross value of more than A$360 million. The industry was worth at least A$70 million to NSW, he said.
In the worst case, fire blight could cost NSW apple and pear producers A$25 million, he said.
